# Adult education in the United Kingdom

Adult schools in the United Kingdom were first formed in 1798 to teach working people to readâ€”and, if they wished, to write. Arithmetic was considered an unsuitable subject on their day of rest. In their heyday, Adult Schools had over one hundred thousand members around the country: the groups affiliated to County Unions and, in 1899, the National Adult School Union was founded. Since then, both the name and the purpose have changed significantly.
In 1965 the National Adult School Organisation (NASO), an advocacy group for adult education in the United Kingdom, headquartered in Harrogate was chartered. NASO was a voluntary organisation with about 80 groups across England. It closed in 2010.
